content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good one

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Great problem!
One suggestion, perhaps change "We say that string is boring when it has length at least 2 and contains only one different character." to "We say that a string is boring when it has a length of at least 2 and contains only one unique character." (It flows better and some people might get confused on what it means by "one different character")

This problem is ambiguous. Take the string "aabba". If I remove "bb" first, I then have to remove all three a's and get the empty string: "". If I remove the first two a's then the two b's, I'm left with one a: "a".

You can resolve this ambiguity by saying you only remove the left-most boring substring each time.

Alternatively (and I prefer this), you can say that a boring string is made of an *even number* of a single repeated character.
I'm open to any suggestions, especially if the statement is not clear, leave a comment, I'll try fix it.

Thanks for this comment. I was wondering that my description could be ambiguous.

I meant that machine removes all occurrences at the same time, so your proposed solutions are incorrect.

I'll add extra explanation to statement.

In that case, you need to add more test cases. Currently, all can be solved by only removing the first boring substring each time. (To show this, change your regex from "/(.)\1+/g" to "/(.)\1+/" and see that it passes all tests when it should not)

Adding example 2 (baabba) as a test case would suffice.

I would also disable the Reverse game mode since it could be too confusing. If you do that and add the test case, I'll approve it.

Done.
I didn't notice that tests hadn't covered this case.
